Moreover, a scripture says, All sentient beings depend on food to live.
If this consciousness did not exist, the substance of that food would not exist.
It is said in a scripture that food is of four kinds:
First, coarse food, characterized by transformation and destruction.

This refers to the three sense objects of smell, taste, and touch in the desire realm. When they transform and are destroyed, they can serve as nourishment. Therefore, the sense object of form is not included in coarse food, because when it transforms and is destroyed, form has no function.
Second, contact food, characterized by contact with objects.
This refers to contaminated contact. When it just grasps an object, it can absorb joy and serve as nourishment.

Although this contact is associated with various consciousnesses, the one belonging to the six consciousnesses is most excellent in meaning as food, because contact with gross and obvious objects, joy, pleasure, and beneficial equanimity, is most excellent in nourishing.
Third, mental intention food, characterized by aspiration.
That is, impure volition that occurs together with craving and hopes for a desirable object can serve as nutriment.

Although this volition is associated with various forms of consciousness, its function of nutriment is especially strong in mental consciousness, because mental consciousness is superior in its hopes and desires concerning objects.
The fourth is consciousness as nutriment, whose characteristic is that of grasping.

That is, impure consciousness increases in power through the force of the material, contact, and volitional nutriments and can serve as nutriment. Although this consciousness is common to all forms of consciousness, the eighth consciousness is especially strong as nutriment, because it is a single species, continues in a series, and grasps its object.
Consequently, the Abhidharmasamuccaya says that these four nutriments are included in three aggregates, five sense bases, and eleven elements.
These four are called nutriments because they sustain the body and life of sentient beings and prevent their destruction.

Material food is useful only in the realm of desire. Contact, volition, and consciousness as nutriment are found throughout the three realms, but they evolve in dependence on consciousness and exist or not depending on its presence or absence.

The evolving consciousnesses such as visual consciousness are interrupted and change objects, and therefore they cannot always and everywhere support life and keep the body. That is, they are interrupted in the samÄdhi of unconsciousness, in deep sleep, in fainting, and among the unconscious celestials.
Even when they are present, they change according to the support, object, nature, realm, stage, etc., and therefore they are not always and everywhere able to support life and keep the body.
Those who maintain that there is no eighth consciousness must explain what kind of nutriment is referred to in the scriptures when they say that all sentient beings are sustained by nutriment.
Past and future dharmas such as consciousness are not nutriment when the mind is unconscious, because they are not present and are as nonexistent as flowers in the sky and have no power.
Even if they have power, they are not present and are like space, etc., and therefore not nutriment.

You cannot say that the mind of one who enters samÄdhi is nutriment for one who is unconscious, because when one is unconscious, the mind has already ceased, and because it has been demonstrated that past does not function as nutriment.

Nor can you say that the food of the sameness of nonidentification is the nonassociated formative forces of the sameness of nonidentification, because they are not included in the four foods of material food, etc., and because nonassociated dharmas are not real.
There is an opinion that in samÄdhi of cessation, etc., there is still a sixth consciousness that can be the food of those sentient beings.
This opinion is unreasonable, as will be discussed later.
Also, they must explain what is the food of sentient beings born in the two upper realms when their minds are pure.
Because pure consciousness, etc., destroy existence, they cannot be food for the body and life of those sentient beings.
You cannot claim that the pure consciousness contains impure seeds that can be food for those sentient beings, because pure consciousness, etc., are like nirvÄá¹‡a and cannot contain impure seeds.
You cannot claim that the body and life of sentient beings in the upper two realms support each other and are each others food, because the four foods do not include body and life.
Also, in the formless realm there is no body, and life has no support, and because the class of sentient beings, etc., have no real substance.

Therefore we know with certainty that apart from the evolving consciousnesses there is a consciousness as retribution that is a single species, is perpetual and universal, holds the body and causes it not to perish, and on the basis of which the World Honored One says that all sentient beings live by means of nutriment.

Sentient beings are established on the basis of the aggregates that are grasped by the passions. The Buddha, being free of outflows, is not included in the category of sentient beings. When it is said that he lives by means of nutriment, you should understand that this is said with a hidden intention.
Since the consciousness as retribution is the best kind of nutriment, that consciousness is the eighth consciousness.

A scripture says that in one who has entered the samÄdhi of cessation, bodily, vocal, and mental actions are all extinguished, yet he is not separated from consciousness, life, or heat. His faculties are not deteriorated, and his consciousness is not separated from his body.

If this eighth consciousness did not exist, one who has entered the samÄdhi of cessation would be separated from his consciousness, because the six consciousnesses, such as visual consciousness, do not exist in a state of samÄdhi, and because the seventh consciousness, i.e., manas, does not exist in this samÄdhi.

The reason is that the characteristics of the six consciousnesses, such as visual consciousness, are gross and unstable, and when they arise with respect to an object, they must be accompanied by mental activities.

Because one is disgusted with them, one temporarily seeks to stop them. Gradually subduing and eliminating them, one reaches the state of complete exhaustion. One is said to abide in the samÄdhi of cessation on the basis of this state, and therefore consciousness ceases in this samÄdhi.
If you do not admit that there is a subtle, single, universal consciousness that holds life, etc., on what do you base the statement that consciousness does not leave the body?

If you say that consciousness returns later, like a case of malaria, and that this is what it means for consciousness not to leave the body, then you should not say that the activities of mind cease, because consciousness arises and ceases together with thought, etc. Life, heat, and the organs would also be like consciousness, and this would be a serious error.
Therefore you must admit that consciousness, like life, heat, etc., does not really leave the body.

Moreover, if there were no consciousness at all in this state, it would be like a piece of tile or stone and not a sentient being. How can you say that it is a person abiding in the samÄdhi of cessation?
Moreover, if the consciousness that is retribution did not exist in this state, what would hold the organs, life, and heat?
If there were no holding, they would be destroyed, just like a dead corpse, and there would be no life, etc.
Therefore the last moment of consciousness does not return to life, and when it is said that consciousness is not separated from the body, to what does this refer?
When the consciousness that is retribution leaves this body, it does not return to life without consciousness.
Also, if there is no consciousness that holds seeds in this state, how can the subsequent consciousness arise without seeds?
Because it has been proven that past, future, non-psychophysical existence, and dharmas unassociated with mind do not really exist.
It has also been refuted that form and other dharmas apart from consciousness are perfumable and hold seeds.

However, in the state of mindless samÄdhi, such as that of cessation, there is consciousness, just as there is in the state of mind, because there is a real basis of the psychophysical complex, life, heat, and sentient beings.
For this reason, one who is in the samÄdhi of cessation definitely has consciousness and does not really leave the body.
If it is claimed that in this state there is a sixth consciousness that is not separated from the body, that also is not reasonable, because this samÄdhi is also called mindless samÄdhi.
If it is called mindless because the five consciousnesses are absent, then all samÄdhis should be called mindless, because all samÄdhis are devoid of the five consciousnesses.
Mental consciousness is included among the six evolving consciousnesses, just as the five consciousnesses do not exist in samÄdhi without conceptualization.
Or, consciousness in this state cannot be known in terms of mode of activity and objects, like life, heat, etc., and is not the sixth consciousness.

If there were consciousness in this state that could be known in terms of mode of activity and objects, it would be like consciousness in other states and would not be included in this state. The reason for entering this samÄdhi is to stop the mode of activity and objects of consciousness.
Also, if there is sixth consciousness in this state, do its mental activities exist or not?
If they exist, the scriptures should not say that in this samÄdhi, all activities of mind cease, nor should they call it the samÄdhi of the cessation of feeling and conceptualization.
The preparatory practice for this samÄdhi is simply the disgust with feeling and conceptualization, and therefore only feeling and conceptualization cease in this samÄdhi.
Feeling and conceptualization are the most powerful of the mental activities and are therefore called activities of mind. What is there to contradict the statement that they cease?
In the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization, only conceptualization would cease, because one is only disgusted with conceptualization.

But you do not admit this, and if only feeling and conceptualization are strong in assisting the mind, then when the two are extinguished, the mind should also be extinguished. If you say that the body still exists when bodily activity is extinguished, why do you insist that the mind must be extinguished when activity is extinguished?
If this is so, then when the activity of speech, i.e., investigation and analysis, is extinguished, speech should not be extinguished, but this is not admitted.

Activity is either universal or non-universal with regard to dharmas. When universal activity is extinguished, the dharma definitely perishes along with it. When non-universal activity is extinguished, the dharma may still remain.
Non-universal activity refers to inhalation and exhalation, because when exhalation is extinguished, the body may still remain.

Investigation and analysis are categorized as universal activities with regard to speech, because when they are extinguished, speech definitely does not exist.ğŸ”½Feeling and conceptualization are also categorized as universal activities with regard to the mind, because we admit that they are like volition, etc., as dharmas that are found in all minds. When feeling and conceptualization are extinguished, the mind definitely perishes along with them. How can you say that they are extinguished and the mind remains?
Also, you admit that volition, etc., are dharmas that are found in all minds. When feeling and conceptualization are extinguished, they should also be extinguished.
If this is so, then faith and so on would also not exist in this state, because the universal mental activities are eliminated and the rest are not present.
How can you say that other mental activities exist?
If you admit that volition and so on are not absent in this state, then feeling and conceptualization must also be present, because they are activities that occur in all states of mind.
Also, if volition and so on exist in this state of samÄdhi, then so must contact, because no mental activity can occur without the power of contact.
If you admit that contact exists, then so must feeling, because feeling is conditioned by contact.
If you admit that feeling exists, then conceptualization must also occur, because they are never separated, just as feeling conditions craving.
Not all feeling generates craving, and therefore not all contact generates feeling. The argument you have advanced is not valid.
They reply:
This is not so, because there is a distinction.

The Buddha himself distinguishes only the feeling born of contact with ignorance as a condition giving rise to craving, and he never distinguishes feeling born of contact. Therefore if there is contact, there must be feeling, and feeling and conceptualization must occur together.
Or, as in other states, feeling and conceptualization must not cease, because you maintain that volition, etc., exist in this state.
If you admit this, you contradict the words of the scriptures that the activities of mind cease, and you cannot establish the samÄdhi of the cessation of feeling and conceptualization.

If there are no mental activities, consciousness must also be absent, because no other mind is seen apart from mental activities, because when the other universal activities cease, the dharma that they condition must also cease, because feeling, etc., would not be mental activities associated with all thought, and because this consciousness would not be associated with a mental activity.
If you admit this, then it must have no support, no object, etc., and it would not be mind, just as material dharmas are not.
Also, a scripture says, Mind, dharmas, and the resulting consciousness, the union of the three is contact, and together with contact there is feeling, conceptualization, and volition.

If there is mental consciousness in this samÄdhi, then the union of the three must produce contact, and contact must be accompanied by feeling, conceptualization, and volition. How can there be consciousness but not mental activities?

If you say that at other times the three are powerful and produce contact, and contact produces feeling, etc., and that because of the disgust with mental activities prior to this samÄdhi, the three things in the samÄdhi are powerless and do not produce contact or feeling, etc.,
then you should call it the samÄdhi of the cessation of mental activities. Why do you say that it is only the cessation of feeling and conceptualization?

If you say that when one is disgusted, one is only disgusted with feeling and conceptualization, and that when these two cease, all mental activities cease, and that the name of the samÄdhi is established on the basis of the disgust that preceded it,

then in that case, mind must also cease in this samÄdhi, because it is associated with the things one is disgusted with, just as are the other mental activities. If not, how can it be called the samÄdhi of the cessation of mind?
Also, what kind of mental consciousness is there in this samÄdhi?
It must not be of the nature of defilement or indeterminate, because these things do not exist in good samÄdhi.

The other defiled and indeterminate minds must have mental activities, because it is not reasonable to detest good and generate the defiled, etc., and because one does not seek quiescence and yet generates distraction.
If you claim that this mind is good because it is associated with good, it must be associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving.
This mind should not be good by nature or good in the ultimate sense, because it contradicts your own tenets, because it is not a root of goodness, etc., and because it is not nirvÄá¹‡a.
If you claim that this mind is good by reason of its origination, because it is attracted and generated by the roots of good of added effort,
this is not reasonable, because it contradicts your own tenets, because, like other good minds, it is not good by reason of its origination.
When a mind of one of the three natures is generated immediately after a good mind, how can a good mind be good by reason of its prior origination?
Therefore, the mind is good by reason of the power of association.
If this is so, then it must be associated with the roots of goodness. How can you claim that this mind alone is devoid of mental activities?
Therefore, if there are no mental activities, there must be no mind either.

When you investigate in this way, you find that the evolving consciousnesses such as visual consciousness are not absent from the concentration of cessation, and therefore the scriptureâ€™s statement that consciousness is not absent from the body means that the eighth consciousness is that consciousness.
It is not stopped when one enters the concentration of cessation, because this consciousness is the most tranquil and stable of all consciousnesses.
The same is true of the state of non-perception and other such states.
A scripture says, Sentient beings are defiled because their minds are defiled, and they are purified because their minds are purified.
If this eighth consciousness did not exist, the defiled mind and the pure mind would not exist.

This is because defiled and pure dharmas have mind as their source, because they are born with mind as their cause and exist supported by mind, and because mind experiences their perfuming and holds their seeds.
Defiled dharmas are of three kinds: passions, karma, and results of karma. They are called defiled because they are the natures of defilement or are associated with defilement.

If this consciousness did not exist, there would be no support for the seeds of the passions, and passions would appear without cause after a pure thought, because no other dharmas can hold the seeds. Past and future do not really exist.

If the passions arose without a cause, then the fruits of learner and beyond-learner in the three vehicles would not exist, because those who have already eliminated the passions would again give rise to them.

If there is no consciousness that holds the seeds of action and its results, then action and its results would arise without a cause after a change of realm or spiritual stage or after a dharma of a different species, because other seeds and other causes have already been refuted.

If action and its results arose without a cause, then after one has entered nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, action and its results in the three realms would arise again, and the passions would also arise without a cause.
Also, the condition of action as a cause of consciousness would not be possible, because the perfuming of the evolving consciousnesses has already been refuted.
The defiled consciousness of the act of rebirth is not attracted by action, and therefore it should be said that the condition of name-and-form is action.
because of the great difference in time, there is no logical connection between the two. Since this is not established, the latter is not established.
Pure dharmas are also of three kinds, because the paths of the two vehicles and the path of bodhisattvas are distinguished according to their differences in elimination and realization.

If there is no eighth consciousness to hold the seeds of the pure dharmas of the two vehicles and bodhisattvas, then these pure dharmas would have no cause when they appear after a period of time, because the other causes that you imagine are already refuted.
If the two pure paths arise without a cause, then after one has entered nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, the two pure paths will arise again, and the support will also arise without a cause.

Also, the supramundane path would not arise for the first time, because there would be no dharma to hold the seeds of that path, because impure dharmas of a different species are not its cause, and because it would arise without a cause.
If it does not arise for the first time, it will not arise later, and in that case the fruits of the paths of the three vehicles would not exist.
If there is no eighth consciousness to hold the seeds of the passions, the fruit of the separation from the obstacle of the passions would not exist.
because when the path is present, neither actual passions nor their seeds exist.

This is because defiled and pure minds do not occur together, because a mind associated with the path does not hold the seeds of passions, because it is contradictory by nature, just as is nirvÄá¹‡a, because future passions and so on are not real, and because it is impossible for other dharmas to hold the seeds.
If there is nothing that is eliminated, then there is no one who eliminates, and on what basis and by virtue of what are the fruits of the religious life established?

If the fruit of the religious life is established on the basis of the nonarising of future passions due to the power of the path, then when the first path arises, one should be a post-learner, because all future passions are forever unarisen due to the absence of a cause.
If this consciousness exists, all of these problems are resolved, because only this consciousness can hold the seeds of the various dharmas.
There are innumerable reasons for proving the existence of this consciousness, but fearing prolixity, we have only given the main ones.
The existence of this separate consciousness is clearly shown by both the holy teachings and reason. All intelligent people should deeply believe in and accept it.
The characteristics of the first transforming consciousness have been discussed.
What are the characteristics of the second transforming consciousness ?

The treatise says:
Next, after the first consciousness that transforms as retribution, we should explain the characteristics of the transforming consciousness that thinks and deliberates.
This consciousness is given a separate name in the holy teachings, called manas, because it constantly and carefully thinks and deliberates, being superior to the other consciousnesses.
How is this name different from the sixth consciousness, mental consciousness?
This is a compound word in which the word for consciousness is elided, like the name Älaya-vijÃ±Äna, because consciousness is the same as manas.
That [sixth consciousness] is a compound word in which the word for consciousness is not elided, like the names eye consciousness, etc., because consciousness is different from manas.
However, the holy teachings fear that this [manas] will be confused with that [sixth consciousness], and therefore the seventh [consciousness] is only called manas.
Also, the name manas is given in order to distinguish it from mind and consciousness, because it accumulates and discriminates in a way inferior to the other two.
Or, in order to show that it is the proximate support of mental consciousness, it is called manas.

That means the first evolving consciousness, because the holy teachings say that this consciousness has as its support the store consciousness.

There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that this manas has as its support the seeds of that consciousness and not the actual mind, because manas is uninterrupted and does not need the actual mind as a simultaneous support in order to be born.

There is an interpretation by DharmapÄla that manas has as its support both the seeds of that consciousness and the actual consciousness, because even though it is uninterrupted, it does change and is called an evolving consciousness, and it must have the actual consciousness as a simultaneous support in order to be born.
Evolving means evolving in a stream, which shows that this consciousness always depends on that consciousness to grasp its object.
All minds and mental activities have a support, but the supports are of three kinds in total:

The first is the support consisting of causal condition, that is, oneâ€™s own seeds. All dharmas are supported on this support, because they will not be produced if they are separated from their own causal conditions.

The second is the support consisting of dominant condition, that is, the six internal sense bases. All mind and its activities are supported on this support, because they will not evolve if separated from the organs that are their associates.

The third is the support consisting of similar and immediately antecedent condition, that is, the mind that has just ceased. All mind and its activities are supported on this support, because they will not arise if separated from the organ that is the guide to their appearance.

Only mind and its activities have the three supports and are said to have a support; this is not so for the rest of the dharmas.ğŸ”½As for the first, the support consisting of seeds, there is an opinion that the present result is born only after the seed has perished, because the Abhidharmasamuccaya says that the result is born after the seed has perished, and because seeds and sprouts, etc., do not exist simultaneously.

There is an interpretation that the above evidence is not conclusive, because the Abhidharmasamuccaya speaks of the production of subsequent seeds, because the production of sprouts, etc., from seeds is not ultimate truth, because the production of sprouts, etc., from seeds is not universally recognized, and because flame and fuel are simultaneous causes.

Therefore the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says, Impermanent dharmas are causes for other natures and also causes for their subsequent moments of self-nature. This is the meaning of the condition as cause.

Next, as for the support of the simultaneous birth of dharmas, there is a theory that the five consciousnesses such as visual consciousness have as their support the sixth, mental consciousness, because when the latter is absent, the former do not exist.
There is no separate eye, etc., that is the simultaneous support, because the five material organs are seeds.
A verse from the Twenty Verses on Consciousness Only says,
Consciousness is born from its own seeds and evolves appearing as an external realm.
In order to establish the internal and external sense bases, the Buddha taught them to be ten.

The meaning of this verse is that the World Honored One, in order to establish the twelve sense bases, taught the seeds of the five consciousnesses to be the eye, etc., and the seen part of the five consciousnesses to be form, etc., as objects. Therefore, the eye, etc., are the seeds of the five consciousnesses.
The Treatise on the Object of Observation also says,
The power of form in consciousness is rightly called the five organs.
Power and form as objects are mutually causes from beginningless time.

The meaning of this verse is that the seeds of form consciousness, such as the eye, etc., born from the perfuming of form consciousness, are called the power of form and are called the five organs. There are no separate eye, etc.
Seeds and form consciousness are always mutually causes, because the perfumer and seeds are causes for each other.
The seventh and eighth consciousnesses have no special support of this kind, because they evolve in a continuous series by their own power.
The sixth consciousness has a special support of this kind, because it must rely on the seventh consciousness in order to arise.

There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that this contradicts reason and the holy teachings, because if the five material organs are the seeds of the five consciousnesses, the seeds of the eighteen elements would be in disorder.
However, the seeds of the eighteen elements are distinct from one another, because this is taught in many places in the holy teachings.
Also, the seeds of the five consciousnesses are different in that they can produce the seeing part and the seen part. Which do you hold to be the organ?
If it is the seeing part, it must be categorized as the aggregate of consciousness.
If it is the seen part, it must be categorized as an external realm.
This contradicts the holy teachings that the five organs of eye, etc., are categorized as the form aggregate and as internal sense bases.

Also, if the five organs are the seeds of the five consciousnesses, the five organs must be the causal condition of the five consciousnesses and should not be said to be categorized as the dominant condition.

Also, if the nose and tongue organs were seeds of the two consciousnesses, then the nose and tongue would be categorized as belonging only to the realm of desire, or the two consciousnesses would be categorized as belonging to the realm of form. If you admit this, then you contradict the holy teachings.
The same is true of the difficulty that the eye, ear, and body organs are seeds of the three consciousnesses and are found in the two realms and five stages.
Also, if the seeds of the five consciousnesses are good or bad, then the five material organs cannot be indeterminate.
Also, if the seeds of the five consciousnesses are categorized as nonappropriated, the five organs would not be categorized as appropriated.
Also, if the five organs are the seeds of the five consciousnesses, then the seeds of mental consciousness would be manas, because the five organs are its homologous cause.

Also, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that the consciousnesses such as visual consciousness are all provided with three supports. If the five material organs are the seeds of the five consciousnesses, the supports would be only two.
Also, the holy teachings say that the organs such as the eyes are both actual dharmas and seeds. If you hold that they are only seeds, you contradict all the holy teachings.

To avoid the above errors, some people cling to the theory and offer this explanation: The seeds of superior karma that can summon the five consciousnesses in the eighth, or store, consciousness are called the five material organs. They are not the causes that produce the seeds of the five consciousnesses. This explanation is wonderful in that it agrees with the two verses and is in accord with the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra.
This explanation is just empty words and has no real meaning, because the five organs would not be indeterminate.
Also, they would not be categorized as appropriated, as belonging to the form aggregate, and as internal sense bases.
The nose and tongue organs would be categorized as belonging only to the realm of desire, and the three organs would not be categorized as belonging to the five stages.
The karma that summons mental consciousness would be manas, and the eye, etc., would not be categorized as both actual dharmas and seeds. Also, the eye, etc., would not be material organs.
Also, if the five consciousnesses are summoned by karma, they would be categorized as indeterminate.

Since the five consciousnesses of good, etc., are not summoned by karma, they would not have the eye, etc., as their simultaneous support. Therefore the above explanation does not constitute a good defense.
Also, many holy teachings say that the Älaya consciousness transforms and appears as material organs, as the location of the organs, and as the world receptacle.
How can you deny the existence of material organs?
You admit that visual consciousness, etc., transform and appear as form, etc., but you do not admit that the organs are transformations of the store consciousness.
This confusion and error seriously violates teachings and reason.
However, when the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says that the seeds and the power of the five organs are the five organs, it is in order to refute the existence of material organs apart from consciousness.

In the case of the eye organ, etc., that is a transformation of consciousness, there is a function of generating the five consciousnesses, and for that reason it is metaphorically called seeds and the power of form, but it is not that the material organs are the karmic seeds of consciousness.

Also, the clear consciousness that has the five sense objects must have the five material consciousnesses as its simultaneous support, because it must be associated with the five material consciousnesses.
If it does not rely on visual consciousness, etc., it must not be the support of the five material consciousnesses, because the power of the two is equal.
Also, although the seventh consciousness is not interrupted, it changes in the path of insight and elsewhere, and therefore must have a simultaneous support, as do the first six consciousnesses.
Otherwise, it would not be categorized as a form of evolving consciousness, and this would contradict the holy teachings that there are seven forms of evolving consciousness.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says, Because there is an store consciousness, manas exists; with manas as a support, manas exists; with manas as a support, mental consciousness evolves.

Therefore we say that the first five consciousnesses each definitely have two simultaneous supports, which are the five material organs and the simultaneous mental consciousness.

Since the seventh and eighth consciousnesses always occur simultaneously, what is wrong with their serving as mutual supports?
